BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in high Alpine regions. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on very steep grassy slopes moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day. The avalanche prone locations for wet avalanches are to be found in particular below approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Fresh wind slabs have settled a little. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger. As a consequence of warming more frequent small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious. These places are quite prevalent but are easy to recognise. As a consequence of warming more frequent small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack especially on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. These can especially at their margins be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.

As a consequence of warming more loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind from northerly directions, clearly visible wind slabs formed. These are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack, in particular on steep sunny slopes. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m. This applies in particular on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase a little in particular on very steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. This applies in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but can in some cases be released easily especially at their margins.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase in particular on very steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Until the temperature falls moist loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by large loads in particular, in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2600 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
The presence of numerous potentially unstable frames is noted, attention to the areas below.
Until the temperature falls more frequent small and medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are possible below approximately 3300 m. This applies on very steep sunny slopes, and in steep rocky terrain.
In particular on very steep grassy slopes more medium-sized ground avalanches are possible between approximately 2400 and 2800 m, in particular on very steep south and southwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual, in particular above approximately 2200 m.
The strong wind has transported a lot of snow.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface at the weekend. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack on very steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 3400 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
In the last few days on very steep grassy slopes several medium-sized avalanches occurred naturally. This applies on south and southwest facing slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The avalanche prone locations are rare but are barely recognisable.

In addition as the day progresses on south facing slopes, further mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible. In the regions with a lot of snow individual gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, wind slabs formed in the last few days in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. These are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released in some cases even by a single winter sport participant. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on very steep grassy slopes moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. The avalanche prone locations for wet avalanches are to be found in particular below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at low and intermediate altitudes. At low altitude only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The Avalanche Warning Service currently has only a small amount of information that has been collected in the field, so that the avalanche danger should be investigated especially thoroughly in the relevant locality.
The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The small wind slabs of the last few days can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. Significant warming above approximately 1000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Gradual increase in danger of moist avalanches until the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed by Friday above approximately 2200 m.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large additional loads. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 2600 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, especially on very steep slopes.
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation a very high danger of moist snow slides will prevail, in particular on extreme sunny slopes, and in steep rocky terrain below approximately 3300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
The strong wind has transported some snow.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack on very steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 3400 m.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface at the weekend.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls. In particular on very steep sunny slopes mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Currently there are quite favourable conditions generally. The old snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in the vicinity of peaks and on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m. A clear night will be followed by favourable conditions, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The older wind slabs are easy for the trained eye to recognise and can only be released in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Isolated small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very early morning: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. In particular on very steep sunny slopes and at higher altitudes individual small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A generally favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The somewhat older wind slabs are small and can only be released in isolated cases. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, especially on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual wet loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. This applies on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They are mostly small and unlikely to be released now. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack especially on sunny slopes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist and wet snow slides are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The small wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 1800 m and on south and southwest facing slopes. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs have formed adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. They are very small and unlikely to be released now. As a consequence of low temperatures a crust will form on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very early morning: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs of the last few days are in individual cases still prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The mostly small wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

In addition as the day progresses on south facing slopes, further mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, mostly small wind slabs formed in the last few days in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. These are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions remain generally favourable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Isolated small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are mostly only small but can be released in isolated cases. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, especially on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual wet loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. This applies on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They are mostly small and unlikely to be released now. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack especially on sunny slopes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist and wet snow slides are still possible.
